awd_titl_txt: Educating the STEM Teacher: From Recruitment into Induction
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, a team at Northern Arizona University (NAU), partnering with Coconino Community College (CCC) and the Flagstaff Unified School District, will recruit and prepare science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors for careers in teaching secondary mathematics and science. The leadership team will include faculty from NAU's College of Engineering, Forestry, and Natural Sciences (CEFNS), including the CEFNS's Center for Science Teaching and Learning, as well as faculty from NAU's College of Education and faculty from CCC. Building on prior funding from the Noyce Program, the project will recruit and prepare 10 new Scholars per year, for a total of 50 new teachers. Each Scholar will receive 1 year of scholarship support either as an undergraduate senior in the NAUTeach program or as a post-baccalaureate graduate student in the Master of Arts in Teaching Science (MAT-S) program.

The project will disburse scholarships for seniors completing a STEM baccalaureate degree with teacher certification and post-baccalaureate mathematics and science majors who enroll in the MAT-S program and will become certified to teach. The project team will then support Scholars during the critical first two years of their teaching careers through continuing professional development in cross-experiential Noyce community of practitioners. To build and strengthen partnerships, the project will provide ambassadorship opportunities with CCC, such as peer tutoring. In addition, the project will offer two courses -- "Inquiry Approaches to Teaching and "Inquiry-based Lesson Design" -- that will enable students at NAU and CCC to explore teaching as a career path. Intellectual Merit rests in the use of quantitative and qualitative data to address evaluation questions that include: To what extent does the design and implementation of the induction program promote educational experiences that support effective mathematics and science instruction for all students? To what extent does the CCC Noyce Partnership broaden participation in mathematics/science teaching careers? What are the impacts of the partnership on the partners and their home institutions? What are the effects of participation in professional learning communities on teachers' mathematics and science instructional practice and professional growth?

por.por_cntn:
The NAU Noyce Scholars Program: Educating the STEM Teacher from Recruitment into Induction (NSF #  1660849) was initiated in 2017 and considered the entire professional development continuum of secondary teachers from recruitment, to teacher preparation, to inservice teaching with induction support. By supporting the entire spectrum of teacher development, the NAU Noyce Scholars Program enhanced the infrastructure for education at NAU, broadened participation in the teaching profession for those who might not otherwise consider STEM teaching, and provided valuable induction support to emerging mathematics and science teachers. The NAU Noyce Scholars Program came to a close in June 2024.

 

NAU Noyce Scholarships/Stipends: The NAU Noyce Fellows Program awarded 52 scholarships/stipends to highly qualified undergraduate and graduate mathematics and science preservice teacher candidates. To date, of scholars who have begun teaching, eight are beginning their first year of teaching, seven have completed one year of teaching, and thirty-six scholars have completed two or more years of teaching. Approximately 40% of recipients were from underrepresented populations, a number well above the national average of 36% for teachers (The New Teacher Project, 2020). In addition to receiving stipend or scholarship support, over 40 Noyce recipients were provided financial support to attend state, regional, and national math or science professional conferences, including regional and national Noyce conferences.

 

NAU Noyce Community College Partnership: In addition to the scholarship/stipend program, the NAU Noyce Scholars Program partnered with a local community college (CCC) in an effort to increase diversity and enrollment in NAU’s secondary mathematics/science education program (NAUTeach) through the development of introductory coursework and peer outreach thereby building relationships with and recruiting students from a local community college. To increase the number of students from CCC entering science or math teaching careers, the leadership team worked with advisors at CCC to recruit interested students to take two introductory NAUTeach courses designed to provide incoming undergraduates curious about or interested in science and math teaching a chance to “try out teaching” in the field. While being offered at CCC, the introductory courses experienced modest success with 5 students enrolling in the first course (Step 1). However, COVID and rebounding enrollments soon made the model of offering these courses at CCC unsustainable. The leadership team changed course and began supporting CCC students to take these courses at NAU through the CCC2NAU program. Since being offered at NAU, six CCC students enrolled and four completed the Step 1 course, and one student went on to complete the Step 2 course. The work of the partnership provided a clearer pathway for those CCC students who want to pursue science or math teaching at the secondary level, through transfer to the NAUTeach program. With the new model for recruitment, CCC students had opportunities to experience NAU courses before considering becoming a full-time student at NAU.

 

NAU Noyce Induction Program: The research-based NAU Noyce Induction program provided online and face-to-face induction support to Noyce scholars and fellows as they became early career teachers. To date, over 100 Noyce graduates, from this project and our previously funded project, have participated in the induction program. The successful 2-year induction program developed in the previous Noyce project was modified for the second year of the program to incorporate an action research component that would help emerging teachers and Noyce scholars to continue growing their practice. First- and second-year teachers received support through PLC structures offered via a virtual synchronous summer conference and monthly virtual synchronous induction sessions. All teachers found the NAU Noyce Program useful or very useful to support them as a new teacher and all teachers found the program to be of high or very high quality. Evidence from previous years indicates that early career teachers appreciate the community of new teachers as a time to share their experiences with other teachers who are experiencing similar challenges and issues.

 

At the time of this report, 94% of scholars who received a Noyce scholarship and participated in induction were employed by a K-12 school compared to 82% of non-participants, indicating that Noyce scholarships and induction has contributed to slightly higher rates of retainment in K-12 schools.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2024
Modified by: Shannon Guerrero
